Award.AwardTitle: Cooperative Learning for Computer Organization and Assembly Language: Curriculum Development and Instructor Training Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to develop more effective methods for teaching topics in computer organization and assembly language programming. A set of cooperative learning activities are being created along with a comprehensive set of instructor support materials, including training videos, to help faculty members learn to use cooperative learning techniques effectively in the classroom. This project builds on previous work on the use of cooperative learning in computer science classes, recognizing the need for fully developed, refined, and tested activities. To increase the number of faculty using cooperative learning techniques, training videos are being created to illustrate the interactions between instructors and their students working on cooperative learning activities. Along with the videos, instructor materials help faculty members learn skills such as observing group processing and selecting (on the spot) the things to bring out during group debriefing. The skills taught in these videos are applicable to any course that utilizes cooperative learning. Because students frequently have difficulty learning computer organization and assembly language, the development and use of more effective ways to teach these topics is expected to lead to improved retention and success in the computer science major.

The project and its materials are undergoing testing and evaluation during development as well as when used outside of the home institution. A variety of faculty workshops help faculty gain facility in using the materials and cooperative learning techniques in their classrooms. Since computer organization and assembly language programming courses are commonly used for transfer credit, some workshops target faculty at community colleges. This work aims to develop and increase computer science faculty awareness and use of cooperative learning activities in the computer science curriculum at a variety of institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of this project were to develop more effective ways for teaching important concepts in computer organization and assembly language programming, to evaluate the effectiveness of these materials and instructional models in improving student learning, with special attention to the needs of students who might otherwise have difficulty succeeding in the course, and to make the results of our work readily available to members of the Computer Science education community. 

We developed a set of classroom exercises and instructional videos, modifying these as indicated during the course of the research.  We used a partially flipped classroom approach, with instructional videos for students to view before class and the use of cooperative learning exercises during class time.  Over the course of the project, we conducted experiments that were designed to measure the effect of student engagement with these videos and exercises, using one section of the underlying course (CS 237) as an experimental group and another section as a control group. Our results have shown statistically significant improvements in student learning that have plateaued in the last year of the project.

From these results, we conclude that our new instructional approaches have been successful in improving student learning of important topics in computer organization and assembly language programming. However, we believe that there are other pedagogical aspects that are relevant for students' learning. For example, one instructor developed his pedagogy and used an in-lesson survey system along with his own exercises. At the same time, a different instructor maintained a similar instructional style while putting his energy into the videos associated with the flipped-classroom approach. The lack of differences between students' learning from the two instructors at the end of the project could speak to the importance of continual adaptation of all instructional tools for student learning.  Even though we are at the end of this NSF-funded project, we hope to continue developing and evaluating these types of tools in the years to come.

We have made the flipped instructional videos available on a website. We conducted a workshop at the ACM-SIGCSE conference in 2018, in which we shared results arising from our work and engaged participants in using our insights to develop their active-learning pedagogy.

We believe that the educational materials developed in this project could have an impact on the way similar courses are taught at other institutions. The general approach used in developing and evaluating the materials has broader application and could be useful in different courses within the discipline.  We hope to stay in contact with workshop participants and other interested parties to share information about their activities and ours.
